Before development time and Resorces were dumped into multiplayer, before a time where companies didn’t spend millions in researching in how to put microtransactions in. Where developers actually cared about the single player experience. Where you paid for a full game, and actually got a full game. 

  I originally bought this when it first come out, just playing half of an hour reminded me how great gaming was back then !  

£0.99....... 99pence for a AAA game. WOW  

Play any game from the last 20 year, and then compare it with how well these games were made back then, it’s clear that the gaming industry is going downhill.

🔲 Dark Souls

🔲 Bad

🔲 Beautiful

🔲 It's there for the people who want it 

✅ Well written 

🔲 Epic story

🔲 Free 

✅ Underpriced 

🔲 Perfect Price

~ LENGTH ~ 

🔲 Extremely Short (60 minutes or less)

🔲 Long (50-90 hours) 

🔲 Extremely long (90-110 hours) 

🔲 No ending 

  

~ FUN ~ 

  

🔲 I'd rather watch paint dry 

🔲 Hard to enjoy 

🔲 Repetitive 

✅ Pretty amusing 

🔲 Ride of your life 

  

~ REPLAYABILITY~ 

  

🔲 Wasn't worth completing 

🔲 It's a one-time experience 

🔲 Only for achievements 

✅ If you wait a few months/years 

🔲 Definitely 

🔲 Infinitely replayable 

  

~ WORTH BUYING ~ 

🔲 STEAMing pile of bantha piss 

🔲 Remove this from the steam store 

🔲 The game needs finishing  

🔲 No 

🔲 Wait for sale 

🔲 Yes 

✅ You NEED to experience this game

Half-Life isn't just a seminal masterpiece that has brought on an entirely new era of gaming, The formula of Run, Shoot, Think. Compounded by the interesting setting, the superlative gun-play and movement, the enemy design, and the confounding multi-faceted, nuanced, and multi-perspective story and lore, make Half-Life a game that has aged like a fine wine, a truly timeless piece that anyone who enjoys games should play. 

If it ended at that though, I wouldn't be writing this review.

Half-Life spawned an entirely new formula for making games that others have replicated countless times, it has influenced countless mods that would go on to become their own franchises, games, or have influenced others to make great games. 

If you play or have played any modern shooter, any story driven first person game, or a game that was based on the engines that facilitated Half-Life, its sequels, and its mods, you have this game to thank, it was the first true story driven shooter.

Its our obligation to recognize greatness when it is present, and this game oozes it in spades.
Still feel good after playing this almost a decade later. Makes my potato laptop feel like a supercomputer :)

So, I recently reviewed Half-Life: Source, the absolutely ABYSMAL Source-run "remaster" of this excellent game. In turn, I'd like to give a review to the original, just to be fair.
Half-Life came out at a time where I had yet to exist. The benefit of Steam and the internet existing is that I don't have to miss out on all these old phenomena that were around when I wasn't alive yet.
Half-Life is one of those experiences that I was very happy to finally play for myself.
I do want to be clear - this game still has flaws. While I feel it isn't always right to judge a game by the standards of a different time, I do also believe that the ability of a game to age over time is important nonetheless. Graphically, Half-Life aged... not so well. Unfortunately, as I stated in my Half-Life: Source review, the official Valve "remaster" wasn't really so much of a "remaster" as it was an over-glorified port. That being said, nostalgia can come into play here. Some may not vibe with looking at every triangle on a model when they play a game. You may not like how pointy the G-Man's chin is. But to be honest, while the game's visuals haven't aged great, they aren't bad. 
Graphics aside, the gameplay is very nice. The running is a bit fast for comfort at times, but the physics engine and combat are very nice, especially considering the time that the game released. Some puzzles can be finicky sometimes, and while game-breaking glitches are something more common in Half-Life: Source, I still occasionally got soft-locked behind blast doors (which is intentional game design, to be fair to Valve here), and there was one point where I needed to supply power to a tram, and it still did not function even after enabling all sources of power (I reset my game save several times and it eventually worked out of nowhere). But this was one minor flaw in an otherwise stellar experience.
The story is simple. It's not overplayed, and it doesn't take the forefront. It gets the player invested while giving the gameplay the reigns and letting it do the talking. It sets up an amazing universe that the remainder of the games take place in, and I cannot recommend it more.
Play Half-Life.
And when you do, make sure it's this version and not the Source port.
P.S., while I praised the physics engine, the platforming is kind of bad. Get used to dying from a long fall. It's a good thing this is a first-person shooter.
